（1）求极性分子 A 在极性分子 B 处产生的电场强度 $\boldsymbol{E}_1$；

（2）求极性分子 B 受到的电场力沿 x 方向的分量 $F_x$，和其受到的绕绝缘轴的力矩 $M$，导出其静止不动的条件；

（3）分析极性分子 B 在其平衡位置（只需要考虑其中 $\theta$ 较小的那个平衡位置）附近的稳定性，求出分子 B 偏离该平衡位置较小时 $x(t)$ 和 $\theta(t)$ 的一般表达式（由于暂未给出初始条件，结果中可包含待定积分常量）；

（4）将极性分子 B 在初始位置 $x=a$ ($0<a<<b$)、$\theta=0$ 处由静止释放，求 $t$ 时刻 $x(t)$ 与 $\theta(t)$ 的具体表达式。

--------------------------------------------------------------------
(1)  Electric field created at B by dipole A  
Dipole A is at the origin, its moment is  
$\displaystyle \mathbf p_1=p\mathbf e_y$.  
For a point dipole

\[
\mathbf E_1(\mathbf R)=k\frac{3(\mathbf p_1\!\cdot\!\hat{\mathbf R})\hat{\mathbf R}-\mathbf p_1}{r^{3}},
\qquad\hat{\mathbf R}=\frac{\mathbf R}{r}.
\]

Because $\mathbf p_1\!\cdot\!\hat{\mathbf R}=p\,b/r$,

\[
\boxed{\;
\mathbf E_1(x,b)=k\,\frac{p}{r^{5}}
\bigl[\,3bx\,\mathbf e_x+(2b^{2}-x^{2})\,\mathbf e_y\bigr]\;}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
(2)  Force along $x$ and torque about the insulating axis on dipole B  

Dipole B has moment  
$\displaystyle\mathbf p_2=p(\sin\theta\,\mathbf e_x+\cos\theta\,\mathbf e_y)$.

•  Torque (out of the $x\!y$ plane)  

\[
M=\bigl(\mathbf p_2\times\mathbf E_1\bigr)_z
     =p\sin\theta\,E_{1y}-p\cos\theta\,E_{1x}
     =k\frac{p^{2}}{r^{5}}\!\left[(2b^{2}-x^{2})\sin\theta-3bx\cos\theta\right].
\]

•  Translational force  

For a permanent point dipole  
$\mathbf F=(\mathbf p_2\!\cdot\!\boldsymbol\nabla)\mathbf E_1
           =\boldsymbol\nabla(\mathbf p_2\!\cdot\!\mathbf E_1).$

Because  
$\mathbf p_2\!\cdot\!\mathbf E_1
      =k\frac{p^{2}}{r^{5}}\bigl[3bx\sin\theta+(2b^{2}-x^{2})\cos\theta\bigr],$

\[
F_x=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}
\!\Bigl(\mathbf p_2\!\cdot\!\mathbf E_1\Bigr)
     =3k\frac{p^{2}}{r^{7}}
      \Bigl[(b^{3}-4bx^{2})\sin\theta+(x^{3}-4b^{2}x)\cos\theta\Bigr].
\]

Static equilibrium requires simultaneously  

\[
\boxed{\,F_x=0\,},\qquad\boxed{\,M=0\,}.
\]

Solving these two equations one obtains the only solutions

\[
\boxed{\;x=0,\quad\theta=0\;\;({\rm parallel})\quad{\rm or}\quad x=0,\quad\theta=\pi\;\;({\rm anti\!-\!parallel})\;}
\]

(the problem later asks us to consider the one with the small $\theta$, i.e. $\theta=0$).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
(3)  Stability and small oscillations about the stable equilibrium  
Take the stable point  

\[
x=0,\qquad\theta=0 ,
\qquad
u\equiv\frac{x}{b}\ll1,\qquad |\theta|\ll1 .
\]

Expand the interaction energy  

\[
U(\mathbf R,\theta)=k\frac{p^{2}}{r^{3}}
        \Bigl[\cos\theta-3(\hat{\mathbf R}\!\cdot\!\mathbf p_1/p)
              (\hat{\mathbf R}\!\cdot\!\mathbf p_2/p)\Bigr]
\]

up to second order in $u,\theta$:

\[
U\simeq\underbrace{-\frac{2k p^{2}}{b^{3}}}_{\text{irrelevant const.}}
      +\alpha\left(\theta^{2}+6u^{2}-3u\theta\right),
      \qquad \alpha\equiv\frac{k p^{2}}{b^{3}}.
\]

Kinetic energy  

\[
T=\frac12 m\dot x^{2}+\frac12 I\dot\theta^{2}
  =\frac12 mb^{2}\dot u^{2}+\frac12 I\dot\theta^{2},
  \qquad I=\frac{1}{12}mb^{2}.
\]

Lagrange equations give the linearised equations of motion

\[
\left\{
\begin{aligned}
mb^{2}\ddot u+12\alpha\,u-3\alpha\,\theta&=0,\\
I\ddot\theta+2\alpha\,\theta-3\alpha\,u&=0.
\end{aligned}
\right.
\]

With $I=\dfrac{mb^{2}}{12}$, the characteristic equation yields

\[
\omega_{1}^{2}=\frac{30\alpha}{mb^{2}}
             =\frac{30p^{2}}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}mb^{5}},\qquad
\omega_{2}^{2}=\frac{ 6\alpha}{mb^{2}}
             =\frac{ 6p^{2}}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}mb^{5}} .
\]

Both eigen-frequencies are real and positive ⇒ the equilibrium $(x,\theta)=(0,0)$ is stable.

The corresponding eigenvectors are  

Mode 1 ($\omega_1$): $\displaystyle\theta=-6u\;(=-6x/b)$,  

Mode 2 ($\omega_2$): $\displaystyle\theta= 2u\;(=2x/b)$.

Hence the general small-oscillation motion is

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
x(t)&=b\Big[A\cos(\omega_{1}t+\delta)+B\cos(\omega_{2}t+\gamma)\Big],\\[4pt]
\theta(t)&=-6A\cos(\omega_{1}t+\delta)+2B\cos(\omega_{2}t+\gamma),
\end{aligned}}
\]

where $A,B,\delta,\gamma$ are determined by the initial conditions.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

Let the particle be released at $t=0$ from  

\[

\]

Choosing phases $\delta=\gamma=0$ (possible because the initial velocities are zero) gives  

\[

\end{aligned}

\]

\[

\begin{aligned}
x(t)&=\frac{a}{4}\Bigl[\cos(\omega_{1}t)+3\cos(\omega_{2}t)\Bigr],\\[4pt]
\theta(t)&=\frac{3a}{2b}\Bigl[\cos(\omega_{2}t)-\cos(\omega_{1}t)\Bigr],
\end{aligned}}
\qquad

\omega_{1}^{2}&=\frac{30p^{2}}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}mb^{5}},\\
\omega_{2}^{2}&=\frac{ 6p^{2}}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}mb^{5}}.
\end{aligned}
\]

$$ y(x,t) = A\cos(kx - \omega t + \varphi_0) = \mathrm{Re}[\tilde{y}(x,t)], \tilde{y}(x,t) = Ae^{i(kx - \omega t + \varphi_0)} = \tilde{A}(x)e^{-i\omega t} $$
其中 $A$、$\omega$、$k$ 和 $\varphi_0$ 分别为振幅、角频率、波矢（可用 $\omega$ 和介质参量表示）和初相位，$\tilde{A}(x) = Ae^{i(kx+\varphi_0)}$ 称为波在 $x$ 处的复振幅。]

具有空间周期性的弹性介质称为“声子晶体”。现讨论角频率为 $\omega$ 的小幅横波在一维弦线上的传播特性。不计重力。

(1) 考虑一根无限长均匀弦线，其质量线密度为 $\rho$、张力为 $\tau$，$x$ 轴沿弦线方向，如图 2a 所示。一列振幅为 $A$、初相位为 0 的简谐波沿 $x$ 轴正方向传播。求在 $t$ 时刻、$x$ 处沿 $x$ 方向单位原长弦线的动能 $\varepsilon_k(x,t)$ 和势能 $\varepsilon_p(x,t)$（取没有波传播时弦线的势能为零），以及瞬时能流 $I(x,t)$ 和平均能流 $\bar{I}$。

(2) 弦线中同时存在沿 $x$ 轴正方向和负方向传播的简谐波时，将这两列波在 $x=x_1$ 处的复振幅分别记为 $\tilde{A}_1$、$\tilde{B}_1$，在 $x=x_2$ 处的复振幅分别记为 $\tilde{A}_2$、$\tilde{B}_2$，$\tilde{A}_2$、$\tilde{B}_2$ 可用 $\tilde{A}_1$、$\tilde{B}_1$ 表示为
$$ \begin{cases} \tilde{A}_2 = \tilde{M}_{11}\tilde{A}_1 + \tilde{M}_{12}\tilde{B}_1 \ \tilde{B}_2 = \tilde{M}_{21}\tilde{A}_1 + \tilde{M}_{22}\tilde{B}_1 \end{cases} \text{，其矩阵表示为} $$

(7)  Which composition produces a stronger Yarkovsky effect?  What spin sense is required to move inwards?

From (5.2) we see that  

  ā_τ ∝ 1 /( ρ^{3/2} √{ κ C } ).

Direction of orbital drift  
Equation (4.3) shows that the tangential recoil is ∝ sin(ωt – δ).  
For a body rotating in the same sense as its orbital motion (prograde) the warm “afternoon’’ hemisphere (φ ≈ +δ) faces the direction of motion, so the recoil points forward and the semi-major axis increases ( dR_a/dt >0 ).

(1)  Boltzmann distribution of the electrons from the 1-D momentum equation

For a stationary, collision–free, one–dimensional plasma the momentum

reduces, at equilibrium ($\partial_t=0,\;v_j=0$), to the force balance  

  $q_j n_{j}(x)E(x)=\dfrac{\mathrm d p_j}{\mathrm d x}$.                      (2)

For isothermal electrons ($T_e$ space– and time–independent) we have  
$p_e=n_ek_BT_e$, hence $\mathrm d p_e/\mathrm d x=k_BT_e\,\mathrm d n_e/\mathrm d x$.  
With $q_e=-e$ and $E=-\mathrm d\phi/\mathrm d x$, Eq.(2) gives  

  $-en_e\left(-\dfrac{\mathrm d\phi}{\mathrm d x}\right)=k_BT_e\dfrac{\mathrm d n_e}{\mathrm d x}$ ⟹  
  $\dfrac{1}{n_e}\dfrac{\mathrm d n_e}{\mathrm d x}=+\dfrac{e}{k_BT_e}\dfrac{\mathrm d\phi}{\mathrm d x}$.  

Integrating from a reference point where $n_e=n_{0}$ and $\phi=0$:

  $\displaystyle n_e(x)=n_{0}\exp\!\left(\dfrac{e\phi(x)}{k_BT_e}\right).$        (3)

Thus the equilibrium electron density indeed obeys the Boltzmann law.

(2)  Debye shielding around a test charge in three dimensions

  $n_j\simeq n_0\!\left[1-\dfrac{q_j\phi}{k_BT_j}\right].$                      (4)

The Poisson equation is

With $q_e=-e$ and $E=-\mathrm d\phi/\mathrm d x$, Eq.(2) gives

  $\displaystyle n_e(x)=n_{0}\exp\!\left(\dfrac{e\phi(x)}{k_BT_e}\right).$        (3)
